p: Total aboveground biomass increased significantly during the 9‐year interval, growing from 337.21 ± 49.82 Mg/ha in 2000 to 366.66 ± 49.98 Mg/ha in 2009. Plot‐size mean increase was 3.27 ± 3.09 Mg/ha per year (bootstrapped 95% CI = 2.88–3.67 Mg/ha per year). Our model selection procedure yielded two GLMs relating biomass change with sets of explanatory variables whose ΔAICc ≤ 2 relative to the model with lowest AICc (Table 1). The three models contained management history alone, or management history in addition to or interacting with functional diversity (Figure 7). Unlogged stands showed significantly greater biomass increases (bootstrapped 95% CI = 4.01–4.74 Mg/ha per year) than early‐logged and recently logged stands (bootstrapped 95% CI = 1.21–2.91 Mg/ha per year, pooled data). Functional diversity was positively related to biomass increase in unlogged plots only. Basal area also increased significantly during the census interval with a plot‐size mean increase of 0.69 ± 0.47 m 2/ha per year (bootstrapped 95% CI = 0.63–0.75 m 2/ha per year), but was not different between logging histories (ANOVA, F = 1.68, df = 2, p = 0.19).
